awd_titl_txt: CAREER: An Integrated Research and Educational Program to Understand Nano Additive Manufacturing by Electrochemical Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award supports fundamental research on a novel nanoscale additive manufacturing process. Additive manufacturing makes three-dimensional objects by adding material at locations specified by the digital computer model of the desired part. Additive manufacturing processes available now can make metal or plastic parts with sizes ranging from several meters to few micrometers only. This award supports fundamental research and education to provide needed knowledge for the development of an additive manufacturing process capable of making parts at nanoscale with sizes in the range of few nanometers to several micrometers through voxel-by-voxel material addition without the need for any support structures. Such parts made from a wide variety of conductive materials have potential applications in biomedical, defense, electronics, energy, healthcare, automotive, or aerospace industries. Therefore, results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society. This research involves several disciplines including manufacturing, electrochemistry, materials science, and control theory. The multi-disciplinary approach will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact engineering education. Specific outreach activities targeting K-12 students, parents and general public are expected to help developing highly educated work force for the next generation advanced manufacturing.
 
The electrochemical additive manufacturing process can overcome several limitations of existing additive manufacturing techniques, such as their inability to achieve sub-micrometer size, intrinsic thermal damage, and inevitable need of support structures to produce overhanging parts. However, some scientific barriers are yet to be overcome to realize electrochemical deposition for additive manufacturing at nanoscale. This research is to fill the knowledge gap on the mechanism(s) of localization during electrochemical deposition at nanoscale. The research team will perform molecular dynamics simulation to understand the mechanism of localization in electrochemical deposition at nanoscale, develop physics-based models to predict deposition rate and residual stress in nano electrochemical deposition and conduct experiments to verify the models, test the hypothesis that nanoscale localization of electro deposition will occur if an electrochemically activated catalyst is involved in the deposition reaction, and establish relationships between process parameters and feasible feature sizes in nanoscale electrochemical deposition.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The research activities conducted as part of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award has helped advance electrochemical additive manufacturing (ECAM), an emerging nontraditional additive manufacturing process capable of material addition without thermal defects. Outcomes of this project include: demonstration of two in-house-built setups to perform electrochemical additive manufacturing - at the nano size scale and via parallelized electrodes. Additionally, a system to model nano-scale ECAM using molecular dynamics was developed.

An experimental system to perform nanoscale electrochemical additive manufacturing (ECAM) was constructed in the form of an electrochemical scanning tunneling microscope (ECSTM) with imaging and deposition functionality. This setup combined essential equipment obtained commercially - piezo tube scanner and combined tip holder-preamplifier - with fully-customized additions built in-house, including: electrochemical tank, additional electrode fixturing, vibration isolation, control hardware, and control software. Functions include: precise tip approach from the visible scale to the nano scale, nano-scale positioning and current monitoring for imaging, and nano pulsing for deposition. A multi-electrode system for scaling up was constructed to build interdigitated parts, which are being increasingly used in sensors and actuators and have a geometry that lends itself to parallelized fabrication. Compared to single-tool deposition, use of a parallel, multi- electrode system helps save time and simplify the tool path in the fabrication of interdigitated parts. The experimental system was built in-house, including custom control hardware and electronics. Deposition of an interdigitated part via multiple tools simultaneously has been demonstrated. 

A molecular dynamics simulation framework was developed to perform nano size-scale modeling of the ECAM process. This included the generation of a localized, nano-scale tool-substrate geometry with solution in between the electrodes. A custom-coded method to apply electrode potentials in a referenced manner and execute the metal ion reduction reaction was developed in accordance with careful understanding of the fundamentals of electrochemistry; such a method was otherwise not readily available via available software packages. 

BROADER IMPACT 

The research outcomes include two new setups to perform electrochemical additive manufacturing - a nanoscale one and a multi-electrode one. Additionally, a method of modeling ECAM at the nano size scale via molecular dynamics simulation was developed. 

In the process of developing these setups, students were exposed to educational opportunities by touring the lab and working in the lab. Every academic semester, one or two class cohorts visited the lab and had a chance to see the research in process presented by graduate and undergraduate students working in the lab; questions and dialogue were encouraged. Several students worked in the lab every semester and were exposed to working with facets of research and development of the processes, including: building of physical setups, coding control systems, conducting experiments, improving the process performance, and helping code features of the molecular dynamics simulation. Various facets of the work were delegated to students; independent, creative thinking and problem solving were encouraged. One student even developed a facile nano pulsing electronic system in-house, something that would have been otherwise costly and difficult to achieve using a commercial setup. Students also had the chance to work in the lab as part of their senior design project for the department, as well as present findings at the UC Undergraduate Scholarly Research Showcase.

This award also assisted with advancing the participation of minorities in advanced manufacturing. Two women students are currently on the PhD track, two women on the MS track, and one undergraduate student in the LSAMP program has made contributions in lab activities over the last several semesters. Working in the lab via this project has exposed these students to be involved in advanced manufacturing research in a way that they may otherwise have not been easily exposed to. Tours and presentations were given to school-children via the Cincinnati Enhanced Engineering Math and Science (CEEMS) program; and an outreach event at UC via the Greater Cincinnati STEM collaborative to expose school children to 3D printing technology.

The project has resulted in 1 US Patent, 2 doctoral dissertations (1 completed, 1 nearing completion), 5 MS theses, 50 refereed publications (47 completed, 3 in preparation). The products in progress are expected to be finalized by June 2022.

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2021
Modified by: Murali Sundaram
